chapters.title: Handling Criticism
chapters.description: Learn to respond to feedback in a healthy way

scenes.text: I've reviewed your project report. There are several areas that need improvement. The data analysis section lacks depth.

choices.text: I'm terrible at my job. I should just quit.
choices.feedback: This is catastrophizing - jumping to an extreme conclusion. Criticism of one task doesn't mean you're bad at everything.

choices.text: Thank you for the feedback. Can you help me understand what specific improvements you'd like to see?
choices.feedback: Excellent! You're staying calm and seeking clarification. This helps you learn and grow.

choices.text: You never appreciate my work. This is unfair!
choices.feedback: Getting defensive blocks learning. Try to see feedback as an opportunity to improve, not a personal attack.

scenes.text: After the meeting, you feel upset. Your inner voice says: 'Everyone thinks I'm incompetent now.'

choices.text: They're right. I'm not good enough for this job.
choices.feedback: This is mind reading - assuming you know what others think. You don't have evidence for this.

choices.text: I made a mistake, but it doesn't define my entire worth. I can learn from this.
choices.feedback: Perfect! You're separating one action from your overall value. This is healthy self-talk.

choices.text: I'll just avoid my manager from now on.
choices.feedback: Avoidance doesn't solve the problem. Facing challenges helps you grow stronger.

scenes.text: Sarah texts: 'Hey! How was your day at work?' How do you respond?

choices.text: Awful. I got criticized and I'm a failure.
choices.feedback: You're catastrophizing again. Try to express your feelings without exaggerating.

choices.text: It was challenging. Got some tough feedback on my report, but I'm working on improving it.
choices.feedback: Great! You're being honest while maintaining perspective. This is emotionally intelligent communication.

choices.text: Fine. Nothing worth talking about.
choices.feedback: Bottling up emotions can increase stress. Sharing with trusted friends helps process feelings.

chapters.title: Managing Anxiety
chapters.description: Control anxious thoughts and find calm

scenes.text: It's 2 AM. You suddenly wake up thinking about tomorrow's presentation. Your heart is racing.

choices.text: Start rehearsing the presentation over and over in your mind.
choices.feedback: Ruminating at night increases anxiety and prevents sleep. Your tired brain won't help you perform better.

choices.text: Take slow, deep breaths. 'I've prepared well. I can handle this. Right now, I need rest.'
choices.feedback: Excellent! Deep breathing calms your nervous system, and reframing helps reduce anxiety.

choices.text: This is going to be a disaster. I should call in sick.
choices.feedback: Avoidance reinforces anxiety. Facing fears (with preparation) is how you build confidence.

scenes.text: Before the presentation, Mike says: 'Wow, you look nervous! Are you okay?'

choices.text: Now everyone will see I'm nervous and think I'm weak!
choices.feedback: Anxiety about anxiety makes it worse. Nervousness is normal and doesn't mean weakness.

choices.text: I'm a bit nervous, but that's normal! It means I care about doing well.
choices.feedback: Perfect! Normalizing nervousness reduces its power. Reframing it as caring is healthy.

choices.text: I'm fine! (while panicking internally)
choices.feedback: Denying emotions doesn't make them go away. Acknowledging feelings helps you manage them.

scenes.text: Mid-presentation, you lose your train of thought for a moment. What do you do?

choices.text: Panic internally: 'Everyone thinks I'm incompetent! This is humiliating!'
choices.feedback: Catastrophizing makes it harder to recover. A brief pause is normal and rarely noticed by others.

choices.text: Take a breath, glance at notes, and continue: 'Let me revisit that point...'
choices.feedback: Excellent composure! Brief pauses show confidence, not weakness. You recovered gracefully.

choices.text: Rush through the rest without pausing, speaking faster.
choices.feedback: Rushing due to anxiety makes things worse. Slowing down helps you regain control.

chapters.title: Positive Self-Talk
chapters.description: Replace negative thoughts with balanced ones

scenes.text: You wake up and immediately think: 'Ugh, another Monday. This week is going to be terrible.'

choices.text: Continue dwelling on how much you hate Mondays.
choices.feedback: Negative predictions create a self-fulfilling prophecy. Your mindset shapes your experience.

choices.text: 'I'm starting fresh. I can't predict the week, but I can handle today.'
choices.feedback: Great! You're staying present and focusing on what you can control. This reduces overwhelm.

choices.text: 'Everything is always perfect! I love Mondays!' (forcing fake positivity)
choices.feedback: Forced positivity isn't genuine. Balanced thinking acknowledges reality while staying hopeful.

scenes.text: You look in the mirror and immediately notice perceived flaws. Your inner critic activates.

choices.text: 'I look awful. Everyone will judge me today.'
choices.feedback: Self-criticism lowers confidence. Others are focused on themselves, not analyzing you.

choices.text: 'I'm human, not perfect. My worth isn't determined by appearance.'
choices.feedback: Excellent self-compassion! You're challenging unrealistic standards and valuing yourself beyond looks.

choices.text: Avoid mirrors for the rest of the day.
choices.feedback: Avoidance doesn't build confidence. Acceptance and self-compassion do.

scenes.text: You didn't get the promotion you applied for. How do you talk to yourself?

choices.text: 'I'm not good enough. I'll never succeed.'
choices.feedback: One setback doesn't define your future. This is overgeneralizing from a single event.

choices.text: 'This is disappointing, but it doesn't mean I'm a failure. I can learn and try again.'
choices.feedback: Perfect resilience! You're acknowledging the feeling while maintaining perspective and hope.

choices.text: 'I don't care anyway. It wasn't important.'
choices.feedback: Minimizing genuine feelings isn't healthy. It's okay to feel disappointed and still move forward.

chapters.title: Effective Communication
chapters.description: Express yourself clearly and listen actively

scenes.text: Your partner forgot an important date you had planned. You feel hurt. How do you express this?

choices.text: 'You never care about what's important to me! You're so selfish!'
choices.feedback: Attacking puts them defensive. Use 'I feel' statements instead of 'You always/never' accusations.

choices.text: 'I feel hurt that our date was forgotten. It was important to me. Can we talk about this?'
choices.feedback: Excellent communication! You expressed feelings without attacking, and invited dialogue.

choices.text: Say nothing, but act cold and distant.
choices.feedback: Passive aggression creates confusion. Clear communication prevents resentment from building.

scenes.text: Your friend is upset and venting about their problems. What's the best response?

choices.text: Immediately jump in with solutions: 'Here's what you should do...'
choices.feedback: Sometimes people need to be heard, not fixed. Ask if they want advice before giving it.

choices.text: 'That sounds really difficult. I'm here for you. Do you want to talk it through or would advice help?'
choices.feedback: Perfect! You validated their feelings and asked what kind of support they need. This is active listening.

choices.text: 'Yeah, my problems are worse. Let me tell you about my day...'
choices.feedback: This shifts focus away from them. Support means being present for their experience first.

scenes.text: Your roommate leaves dishes piling up constantly. You need to address this. How?

choices.text: Leave a passive-aggressive note: 'Some people are slobs.'
choices.feedback: This creates hostility without solving the problem. Direct conversation is more effective.

choices.text: 'Hey, can we talk about the dishes? I feel stressed when they pile up. Can we create a system that works for both of us?'
choices.feedback: Excellent! You shared your feelings, stated the problem, and invited collaboration on a solution.

choices.text: Say nothing and silently resent them while doing all dishes.
choices.feedback: Avoiding conflict builds resentment. Healthy relationships require expressing needs respectfully.

scenes.text: You're offered a leadership role at work, but you immediately think: 'I'm not qualified enough for this.'

choices.text: Decline immediately: 'I can't do this. Someone else is better suited.'
choices.feedback: Imposter syndrome makes you underestimate yourself. Growth happens outside comfort zones.

choices.text: 'I may not have all the answers yet, but I have valuable skills and can learn. I'll take this challenge.'
choices.feedback: Excellent confidence! You acknowledged uncertainty while recognizing your capabilities and growth potential.

choices.text: 'I'm perfect for this! I know everything already.'
choices.feedback: Overconfidence without humility can backfire. Balanced confidence includes knowing you can learn.

scenes.text: At a networking event, you feel intimidated by successful people around you. What do you tell yourself?

choices.text: 'Everyone here is more accomplished than me. I don't belong.'
choices.feedback: Comparing yourself to others' highlight reels hurts confidence. Everyone has their own journey.

choices.text: 'I have unique experiences and perspectives to offer. I belong here just as much as anyone.'
choices.feedback: Perfect! You're recognizing your own value instead of measuring against others. This is true confidence.

choices.text: Hide in the corner and leave early.
choices.feedback: Avoidance prevents growth. Confidence builds through action, even when uncomfortable.

scenes.text: You made an error in front of your team. You feel embarrassed. How do you recover?

choices.text: 'I'm so stupid. They'll never respect me now.'
choices.feedback: One mistake doesn't erase your competence. Self-compassion after errors is crucial for confidence.

choices.text: 'I made a mistake, and that's human. I'll acknowledge it, fix it, and move forward.'
choices.feedback: Excellent resilience! Owning mistakes without self-flagellation shows true confidence and maturity.

choices.text: Make excuses and blame others to save face.
choices.feedback: Defensiveness undermines trust. Confident people can admit errors without losing self-worth.

scenes.text: You have three deadlines, family obligations, and your car broke down. You feel completely overwhelmed.

choices.text: 'I can't handle this! Everything is falling apart! I'm going to fail at everything!'
choices.feedback: Catastrophizing increases stress. Breaking problems into smaller pieces makes them manageable.

choices.text: 'This is a lot, but I can prioritize. First, what absolutely must be done today? I'll handle one thing at a time.'
choices.feedback: Excellent coping! Prioritizing and taking it step-by-step reduces overwhelm and increases control.

choices.text: Procrastinate by scrolling social media to avoid thinking about it.
choices.feedback: Avoidance increases anxiety. Facing stressors with a plan reduces them.

scenes.text: Your friend asks you to help them move this weekend, but you're already exhausted and overscheduled.

choices.text: Say yes despite being burned out, feeling resentful.
choices.feedback: Saying yes when you mean no builds resentment and burnout. Healthy boundaries protect your well-being.

choices.text: 'I really wish I could help, but I'm completely exhausted this weekend. Can I help you another way?'
choices.feedback: Perfect boundary-setting! You declined respectfully while showing you care. This protects your mental health.

choices.text: 'No! I'm way too busy! Find someone else!'
choices.feedback: You can set boundaries while still being kind. Respectful 'no' maintains relationships.

scenes.text: You're exhausted, but there's still work you could do tonight. What do you choose?

choices.text: Push through exhaustion to finish everything tonight.
choices.feedback: Burnout reduces productivity and harms health. Rest is productive - it restores your energy.

choices.text: 'I've done enough today. Resting now will help me perform better tomorrow. I'm taking the evening off.'
choices.feedback: Excellent self-care! Recognizing limits and prioritizing rest prevents burnout and sustains long-term performance.

choices.text: Feel guilty about resting but do it anyway, unable to enjoy it.
choices.feedback: Rest without guilt is important. You deserve recovery time - it's not laziness, it's necessary.
